title: 110_hr244
content: The Act may be cited as the "Technology Retraining and Investment Now Act for the 21st Century". The Congress finds that the value added by workers in the US and other countries is increasingly dependent on educational and training investments. There is a disparity in investment between the US and its trading partners, leading to declining educational performance. US businesses struggle to fund worker education compared to other countries. In an increasingly global and competitive marketplace, US businesses find it difficult to fund worker education compared to other countries. The current workforce environment puts pressure on domestic companies to utilize highly educated knowledge workers from other countries. It is crucial for the US government to reverse this trend to support national security, the middle class, and workers' welfare. Public-private partnerships in the US, like the research and development tax credit, help address these challenges. The United States utilizes public-private partnerships, like the research and development tax credit, to enhance competitiveness globally. Businesses play a crucial role in training the workforce for high-paying technology jobs to support retiring baby boomers and incentivize mature workers to retrain for new roles. The Act aims to encourage businesses to invest in training for high-paying information and communications technology jobs to support retirees and help mature workers retrain for new roles. It also incentivizes employers to train workers in skills necessary for business expansion and maintenance. SEC. 30D. Information and Communications Technology Education and Training Program Expenses are eligible for a tax credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This aims to support businesses investing in training for high-paying jobs and retraining mature workers for new roles. The tax code allows a credit of 50% for information and communications technology education and training expenses incurred by a taxpayer for the benefit of employees. The credit is limited to $4,000 per individual per year. The tax code allows a credit of 50% for information and communications technology education and training expenses incurred by a taxpayer for the benefit of employees. The amount of expenses taken into account for any individual in a taxable year cannot exceed $4,000, but this limit can increase to $5,000 for certain programs and individuals, such as those in empowerment zones or school districts with a high percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches. In subchapter X, the tax credit applies to expenses incurred for employees in specific school districts with at least 50% of students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches, designated disaster areas, or rural enterprise communities. The Emergency Assistance Act provides tax credits for expenses incurred in designated rural areas, tribal jurisdictions, or by small employers. The Emergency Assistance Act offers tax credits for information technology education and training program expenses incurred by small employers with 200 or fewer employees for at least 20 weeks in a year, or for individuals with disabilities. These expenses cover course work, certification testing, and programs registered by the Department of Labor. The Emergency Assistance Act provides tax credits for information technology education and training program expenses, including course work, certification testing, and essential expenses for skill assessment. The term 'information technology education and training program' refers to training in information and communications technology disciplines provided by accredited institutions or employers. Commercial information technology training providers are also included in the definition. The Emergency Assistance Act offers tax credits for IT education and training expenses at various institutions or employer-owned training organizations. Commercial IT training providers are also eligible. No double benefits are allowed under other provisions. The training programs must use industry-recognized disciplines and evaluation methods. No double benefits are allowed for expenses under other provisions. The credit allowed for IT education and training expenses shall not exceed the regular tax reduced by other credits. The credit for IT education and training expenses is subject to rules similar to section 45A(e)(2) and subsections (c), (d), and (e) of section 52. The credit cannot exceed the regular tax reduced by other credits, over the tentative minimum tax for the taxable year. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to amounts paid or incurred in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4 amends the definition of an eligible educational institution to include institutions described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and commercial information and communications technology training providers. It also makes a conforming amendment to the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board is established with up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Board develops guidelines for computer science and information technology courses and certifications for approval under the Internal Revenue Code. Meetings are held at least annually, and a Chairperson is elected from among members who are part of an IT industry trade association. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board is responsible for developing guidelines for computer science and information technology courses and certifications for approval under the Internal Revenue Code. The Board submits a list of approved certifications to the Secretary of the Treasury annually. Board members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Board is not subject to termination under the Federal Advisory Committee Act.
